description.narrative: Projektet kommer att fokusera på lokala strategiska aktörer (civila samhällsorganisationer samt sk lokala ledare) i södra Syrien och utveckla deras färdigheter i att bättre kunna samordna nätverk och skapa institutioner som grundar sig på ett rättighetsperspektiv. Fokus kommer ligga på att ge projektets deltagare kunskaper och instrument för implementering av mänskliga rättigheter och institutionella strukturer, samt att fostra en kultur av mänskliga rättigheter hos nya och framtida institutioner med syfte att säkra rättigheter. I och med den senaste förlängningen med aktivitetsperiod till 30 September 2018 kommer projektet att pågå under 48 månader till en totalkostnad av 10 900 000 kronor med den föreslagna kostnadsförlängningen. Förlängningen som innebär ett tillägg på 3 500 000 kronor under nio månader innebär också att Etana expanderar sitt arbete, till exempel utvecklas kvinnonätverket som tidigare ingått i fredsnätverket som en egen komponent. Etana utökar också sitt arbete i alla de övriga komponenterna, dvs frednätverket, arbetet med kulturcentra, analysarbetet samt det internationella påverkansarbetet. Expansionen kommer att vara en viktig del av diskussionen om en eventuell ny projektperiod efter förlängningen.

The project will focus on local strategic actors (civil society organizations and so-called community leaders) in southern Syria and build their capacity to better coordinate different networks and create institutions based on a rights perspective. The focus is to give participants knowledge of Human Rights instruments and institutional structures, as well as to foster a culture of Human Rights among new and emerging institutions to secure rights.

Through the “Syrian Citizens Action Network”, local leaders and organizations in the South of Syria are reunited on the basis of their original common goal of building a better Syria that is peaceful, stable and inclusive; and they are empowered to lead their people towards this brighter future for all. The specific objectives are: I. A comprehensive understanding of human rights, gender equality and democratic institutions by local leaders and civil society activists in the South of Syria. II. An increase in the possession of skills related to networking, communication and advocacy by civil society activists in the South of Syria. III. Increased capacity of local leaders in the South Syria to build inclusive and democratic institutions. IV. Local leaders and civil society activists in the South of Syria are connected, united and empowered to formulate recommendations and solutions to the conflict that enjoy broad support among their communities and will drive Syria towards inclusive and sustainable peace. V. Local leaders and civil society activists in the South of Syria are empowered to advocate and promote their recommendations and solutions on a local, national and international level.

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The main result is he recruitment and establishment of the Peace Network in Southern Syria from 2014 and onwards. In line with the objectives the network managed already the first year to reduce local hostilities related to the conflict. A core activity in the network has been strengthening local leaders in human rights, democratic skills and peace building. Free Women’s Network was also a result of the Peace Network until 2018 when it was integrated in the network. Etana’s network was also instrumental in the negotiations between opposition groups and the regime in South Syria July 2018 when the regime took control of the Southern provinces. The peace network was activated to mitigate and decrease any violence the peace network, in Daraa the network facilitated return of civilians to their normal life and worked for former government employees' return to their employment. Etana has used it’s network and built up relation and accountability between grassroot communities and negotiation bodies, much due to the mistrust between the civil society and the political body of the opposition. In parallel with this work Etana has during the project period built up the research function and continued the international advocacy activities. The research function relates to all components in the project as it is through the network that much of the information and analysis is collected, but also as it nourishes all the advocacy work as well as peace building activities in a strategic way. Etana regularly produce emergency briefings on the most urgent developments or in-depth studies to understand complex dynamics and assess trends.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
